revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1888 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]] (coached by [[Walter Camp]]) '''Events''' * Tackling below the waist is legalised.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[FA Cup final]] – [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] 2–1 [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at [[The Oval]] * Walsall Town and Walsall Swifts merge to form [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall Football Club]]. The club initially plays under the name of Walsall Town Swifts. * Small Heath, later [[Birmingham City]], is the first football club to form a limited company * 7 April — [[Tinsley Lindley]] scores in his ninth consecutive [[England national football team|England]] game, a [[England national football team records|record]] that still stands. '''Origin of the Football League''' * One of the problems facing [[professionalism]] is the lack of competitive matches, especially for teams that have been knocked out of the [[FA Cup]]. It is self–evident that crowds for friendly fixtures are much lower, which means a reduction in revenue and consequent struggle to pay wages. * [[Aston Villa]]'s Scottish director [[William McGregor (football)|William McGregor]] seeks a solution by asking other professional clubs to arrange annual home and away fixtures on a competitive basis, with points to be awarded for winning and drawing. Following a conference between club directors on 23 March, the English [[Football League]] is founded on 17 April as one division of twelve clubs. * The founder members are: [[Accrington F.C.]] (1888–1893), [[Aston Villa]], [[Blackburn Rovers]], [[Bolton Wanderers]], [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], [[Notts County]], [[Preston North End]], [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke F.C.]], [[West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. '''India''' * [[Durand Cup]] instituted by [[Mortimer Durand]] as recreation for British troops stationed in India. It is the oldest tournament in India and the third oldest in the world. '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Cup final]] – [[Renton F.C.|Renton]] 6–1 [[Cambuslang F.C.|Cambuslang]] * [[Celtic Football Club]] is founded by members of the Marist Order, a teaching institute, as a way of raising money for a poor children's charity. The club's first ground is a piece of rented land not far from the present [[Celtic Park]]. Celtic's first recorded match is a home "friendly" against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]; Celtic win 5–2 in what is therefore the inaugural "[[Old Firm|Old Firm Game]]".
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] v. [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] – [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) defeats [[Saint Louis Cardinals]] (AA) 6 games to 4. '''Events''' * The last of many adjustments finally sets four balls and three strikes for a "walk" and a strikeout.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural [[World Welterweight Champion]] is [[Paddy Duffy]] of Boston, Massachusetts who is recognised following his 17th round knockout of [[Billy McMillan (boxer)|Billy McMillan]] at Fort Foote, Virginia on 30 October.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone – Lineal Welterweight Champions |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/welter.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hYqUZkyn?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/welter.htm |archivedate=2009-06-15 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-13 |df= }}</ref> Duffy retains the title until his death (by tuberculosis) in 1890. The [[welterweight]] division is for fighters weighing between 140 and 147lb. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John L. Sullivan]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Nonpareil Dempsey]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Paddy Duffy]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack McAuliffe (boxer)|Jack McAuliffe]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * After a run of disastrous results over a number of seasons, [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] is demoted from first-class status and the 1888 championship is contested by only eight teams: Gloucestershire, Kent, Lancashire, Middlesex, Nottinghamshire, Surrey, Sussex and Yorkshire. Derbyshire will recover first-class status in 1894 and join the official County Championship in 1895. * 5 July — formation of [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club]] at a meeting in the [[Angel Hotel, Cardiff]]. * Thanks mainly to the bowling of [[Bobby Peel]], [[England national cricket team|England]] defeats [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] 2–1 to retain [[The Ashes]]. '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 1,886 @ 32.51 (HS 215) * Most wickets – [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]] 283 @ 11.68 (BB 9–15) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Six Great Bowlers of the Year]] – [[George Lohmann]], [[Johnny Briggs (cricketer)|Johnny Briggs]], [[John Ferris (cricketer)|John Ferris]], [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]], [[Sammy Woods]], [[Bobby Peel]] '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Harry Moses]] 815 @ 62.69 (HS 297*) * Most wickets – [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]] 106 @ 13.59 (BB 8–39)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1888 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Jack Burns (golfer)|Jack Burns]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1888 Grand National|Grand National]] – Playfair * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Briar-root * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Ayrshire (horse)|Ayrshire]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Ayrshire * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Seabreeze (horse)|Seabreeze]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Seabreeze '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Mentor '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Harry Cooper '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – The Maroon * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Theodolite '''USA''' * [[1888 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – MacBeth II * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Refund * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Sir Dixon * [[The Futurity]] – Proctor Knott
==[[Ice hockey]]== * March 15 – [[Montreal Hockey Club]] defeats [[Montreal Victorias]] 2–1 in a playoff to capture the [[1888 AHAC season|1888 AHAC championship]].
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 24 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 45th [[The Boat Race 1888|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * The [[1888 Home Nations Championship]] is the 6th series of the [[Six Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] contested by [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]], [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]. England is excluded due to its refusal to join the [[International Rugby Board]]. The teams win one match apiece and the title is shared by all three. '''Other events''' * The [[1888 British Lions tour to New Zealand and Australia|1888 British Isles tour of New Zealand and Australia]] sees the first overseas touring rugby team from Britain. The tour is a private venture and not authorised by the Home Nations. * The [[1888–1889 New Zealand Native football team]] are the first overseas rugby tourists from the Southern Hemisphere. The team plays matches under [[Rugby union|Rugby football]], [[Australian rules football|Victorian Rules football]] and [[Football (soccer)|Association football]] codes. * [[Bristol Bears|Bristol Football Club]] is formed when the Carlton club merges with rival club Redland Park to create a united Bristol team.
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Ernest Renshaw]] (GB) defeats [[Herbert Lawford]] (GB) 6–3 7–5 6–0 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Lottie Dod]] (GB) defeats [[Blanche Bingley Hillyard]] (GB) 6–3 6–3 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Henry Slocum (tennis)|Henry Slocum]] (USA) defeats [[Howard A. Taylor]] (USA) 6–4 6–1 6–0 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Bertha Townsend]] (USA) defeats [[Ellen Hansell]] (USA) 6–3 6–5
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1888 in sports| ]]

'''1954 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
{{Year box}}
==[[American football]]== * [[1954 NFL Championship Game|NFL Championship]] – [[Cleveland Browns]] win 56-10 over the [[Detroit Lions]] * [[1954 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] (1953 season): ** The [[Maryland Terrapins]] lose 7-0 to the [[Oklahoma Sooners]]; still voted national champions by the [[AP Poll|AP]] and [[Coaches Poll]] * [[1954 college football season]] ** The [[UCLA Bruins]] finish #1 in the Coaches Poll and share the [[List of college football national champions|national championship]] (don't play in the [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] due to the "no-repeat rule")
==[[Artistic gymnastics]]== * [[1954 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships|1954 World Championships]] ** Men's all-around champion – [[Viktor Chukarin]], [[USSR]] ** Women's all-around champion – [[Galina Rud'ko]], [[USSR]] ** Team competition champions – men's – USSR; women's – USSR
==[[Association football]]== '''[[FIFA World Cup]]''' * [[1954 FIFA World Cup|1954 World Cup]] held in Switzerland. [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] beat [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] 3-2. '''England''' * [[1953–54 Football League|First Division]] – [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] win the [[1953–54 in English football|1953–54]] title. * [[1953–54 FA Cup|FA Cup]] – [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] beat [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] 3-2. '''Spain''' * [[1953–54 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[Real Madrid]] '''Italy''' * [[1953–54 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[F.C. Internazionale Milano]] '''West Germany''' * [[1954 German football championship|German football championship]] won by [[Hannover 96]] '''France''' * [[1953–54 French Division 1|French Division 1]] won by [[Lille OSC]] '''Portugal''' * [[1953–54 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Liga]] won by [[Sporting C.P.]] '''Other events''' * May 8 – The [[Asian Football Confederation]] is founded in [[Manila]]. * June 15 – [[UEFA]] is founded in [[Basel]].
==[[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]]== * May 6 – [[Roger Bannister]] breaks the [[four-minute mile]] barrier with a time of 3:59.4 * August 25 to 29 August – [[1954 European Championships in Athletics|European Championships]] held at Berne, capital of Switzerland
==[[Australian rules football]]== *[[Victorian Football League (1897–1989)|Victorian Football League]] ** 5 June: Champion [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] full-forward [[John Coleman (Australian footballer)|John Coleman]] has his career ended by a serious knee injury ** [[Footscray Football Club|Footscray]] wins the 58th VFL Premiership by defeating [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] 15.12 (102) to 7.9 (51) [[1954 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]]. ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Roy Wright (footballer)|Roy Wright]] ([[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]]) *[[South Australian National Football League]] ** [[Port Adelaide Magpies Football Club|Port Adelaide]] begins a record run of six consecutive [[South Australian National Football League|SANFL]] premierships by beating [[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]] 11.13 (79) to 10.16 (76) in a highly controversial Grand Final. ** [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Len Fitzgerald]] ([[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]]) *[[Western Australian Football League|West Australian National Football League]] ** {{WAFL SF}} wins its third successive premiership and eighth overall beating {{WAFL EF}} 21.14 (140) to 9.8 (62). ** [[Sandover Medal]] awarded to [[Merv McIntosh]] ([[Perth Football Club|Perth]])
==[[Baseball]]== * January 14 – Former [[New York Yankees|Yankees]] great [[Joe DiMaggio]] marries actress [[Marilyn Monroe]] in a union of heavily publicized media stars. * [[St. Louis Browns]] move to Baltimore, Maryland, becoming the ''new'' [[Baltimore Orioles]]. * [[1954 World Series|World Series]] – [[1954 New York Giants (MLB) season|New York Giants]] win 4 games to 0 over [[1954 Cleveland Indians season|the Cleveland Indians]]
==[[Basketball]]== * [[1954 FIBA World Championship|FIBA World Championship]] – ** Gold: United States ** Silver: Brazil ** Bronze: [[Philippines]] * [[NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]] – **La Salle wins 92-76 over Bradley * [[1954 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] – ** [[1953–54 Minneapolis Lakers season|Minneapolis Lakers]] win 4-3 over [[1953–54 Syracuse Nationals season|the Syracuse Nationals]] * March 13 – [[1954 Milan High School basketball team|Milan High School]], enrollment 161, defeated [[Muncie, Indiana|Muncie]] Central High School (enrollment over 1,600) 32-30 to win the [[Indiana]] state title. The 1986 movie classic ''[[Hoosiers (film)|Hoosiers]]'' was very loosely based on the story of this Milan team.
==[[Boxing]]== * September 17 in New York City, [[Rocky Marciano]] retained his World Heavyweight title with an 8th-round knockout of [[Ezzard Charles]] * December 12 – death of [[Ed Sanders (boxer)|Ed Sanders]] (24), American heavyweight soon after a fight with Willie James in which he lost consciousness
==[[Canadian football]]== * The [[BC Lions]] started play in the [[Canadian Football League West Division#Western Interprovincial Football Union (1936–1961)|Western Interprovincial Football Union]] as the ninth professional team. * After the 1954 season, the [[Ontario Rugby Football Union]] stops challenging for the [[Grey Cup]], permanently establishing that trophy as one to be awarded only to [[professional sport|professional]] teams. * These changes result in the Grey Cup being an [[Eastern Canada|East]] vs. [[Western Canada|West]] competition. Although the [[Canadian Football League]] was not technically founded until [[1958 in sports|1958]], 1954 is often referred to as the start of the "modern era" of Canadian professional football. It is also considered to be the year the CFL was founded in substance if not in name. * In the Grey Cup, the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] win 26-25 over the [[Montreal Alouettes]]. * The [[Canadian Intermediate-Senior championship]] was awarded to the [http://web.ncf.ca/lavitt/1954winnipegrams.html Winnipeg Rams]. The team consisted of [http://www.wilds.mb.ca/rich] Rich Kolisnyk (quarterback), Mel Kotch, Bob Jones, Tom Brisson, Bill Ritchie, Len Sigurdson, Walt Van Wynsberg, Lorne Miller, [[Gerry Duguid]], Harry Makin, Art Makin, Jerry Lavitt, John Thorney, Bill Barrett, Jim Thorney, Al McBride, Bill Senyk, Bob Bouchard, Ray Charambura, Nick Miller, Dick Hebertson, Ron Stephenson, Al Passman, Mort Corrin, Bill Yee, Norm Lampe, Dede Brown, Joe Sawchuk, Art Brockhill, Lew Miles, Ken Freeman, Bill Thomas, Ron Cooke, Pete Sawchuk, Harry Snider, Harold Neufeld and their mascot Ken Kolisnyk.
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[1954 World Figure Skating Championships|World Figure Skating Championships]] – ** Men's champion: [[Hayes Alan Jenkins]], United States ** Ladies’ champion: [[Gundi Busch]], Germany ** Pair skating champions: [[Frances Dafoe]] & [[Norris Bowden]], Canada ** Ice dancing champions: [[Jean Westwood (figure skater)|Jean Westwood]] & [[Lawrence Demmy]], Great Britain
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1954 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Sam Snead]] * [[1954 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Ed Furgol]] * [[1954 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Peter Thomson (golfer)|Peter Thomson]] * [[1954 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Chick Harbert]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Bob Toski]] – $65,820 '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Doug Bachli]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Arnold Palmer]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Betty Jameson]] * [[1954 U.S. Women's Open Golf Championship|U.S. Women's Open]] – [[Babe Zaharias]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Louise Suggs]] * [[LPGA|LPGA Tour]] money leader – [[Patty Berg]] – $16,011
==[[Harness racing]]== * [[Little Brown Jug (horse racing)|Little Brown Jug]] for pacers won by [[Adios Harry]] * [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] for trotters won by [[Newport Dream]] * [[Australian Inter Dominion Harness Racing Championship]] – ** Pacers: [[Tennessee Sky]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Four Ten]] * [[1954 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Royal Tan]] '''Hurdle races''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – [[Sir Ken (horse)|Sir Ken]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Rising Fast]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Collisteo]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Sica Boy]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Zarathustra (horse)|Zarathustra]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Darius (horse)|Darius]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Never Say Die (horse)|Never Say Die]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Never Say Die (horse)|Never Say Die]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1954 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Determine]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Hasty Road]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[High Gun]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[Art Ross Trophy]] as the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s leading scorer during the regular season: [[Gordie Howe]], [[Detroit Red Wings]] * [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] for the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s Most Valuable Player: [[Al Rollins]], [[Chicago Blackhawks|Chicago Black Hawks]] * [[1954 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]] – [[1953–54 Detroit Red Wings season|Detroit Red Wings]] win 4 games to 3 over [[1953–54 Montreal Canadiens season|the Montreal Canadiens]] * [[World Hockey Championship]] ** Men's champion: [[Soviet Union|USSR]] wins 7-2 over Canada's [[East York Lyndhursts]]. * [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship]] – [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] Engineers defeat [[University of Minnesota]] Golden Gophers 5-4 in overtime in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]]
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1954 in motorsport|List of 1954 motorsport champions}}
==[[Rugby league]]== * May 5 – [[1953–54 Northern Rugby Football League season#Challenge Cup|1953–54]] [[Challenge Cup]] Final replay is won 8–4 by [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]] against [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] before a world record crowd for a rugby football match of either code of over 120,000 at [[Odsal Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news | last =Baker | first =Andrew | title =100 years of rugby league: From the great divide to the Super era | newspaper = [[The Independent|Independent, The]] | publisher =independent.co.uk | date =1995-08-20 | url =https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/100–years–of–rugby–league–from–the–great–divide–to–the–super–era–1597130.html | accessdate =2009-09-25 }}</ref> * May 8 – [[1953–54 Northern Rugby Football League season]] culminates in [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]]'s 8–7 win over [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] in the Championship Final at [[Maine Road]] before 36,519. * September 18 – [[1954 NSWRFL season]] culminates in [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]]'s 23–15 win over [[Newtown Jets|Newtown]] in the grand final at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] before a crowd of 45,759 * November 13 – [[1954 Rugby League World Cup|first World Cup tournament]] culminates in [[Great Britain national rugby league team|Great Britain]]'s 16 – 12 win over [[France national rugby league team|France]] in the final.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = England beats France to win rugby crown | work = The Milwaukee Journal | place = | pages = 9 | language = | publisher = | date = 1954-11-13 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fAYvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hSMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1256,6515278 | accessdate = 2009-12-25}}</ref> * December 13 – the final match of the [[1953–54 European Rugby League Championship|1953–54 European Championship]] was played, with England finishing on top of the tournament ladder to claim the championship.
==[[Rugby union]]== * 60th [[1954 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is shared by [[England national rugby union team|England]], [[France national rugby union team|France]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]. This is the first time that France either wins or shares the title.
==[[Skiing]]== * [[ISF World Championships]] – **Men's combined champion: [[Stein Eriksen]], Norway **Women's combined champion: [[Ida Schöpfer]], Switzerland
==[[Snooker]]== * [[World Snooker Championship]] – [[Fred Davis (snooker player)|Fred Davis]] beats [[Walter Donaldson (snooker player)|Walter Donaldson]] 39-21
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Mervyn Rose]] (Australia) defeats [[Rex Hartwig]] (Australia) 6–2, 0–6, 6–4, 6–2 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Thelma Coyne Long]] (Australia) defeats [[Jenny Staley Hoad]] (Australia) 6–3, 6–4 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jaroslav Drobný]] (Egypt) defeats [[Ken Rosewall]] (Australia) 13–11, 4–6, 6–2, 9–7 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Maureen Connolly Brinker]] (USA) defeats [[Louise Brough Clapp]] (USA) 6–2, 7–5 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – '''Davis Cup''' * [[1954 Davis Cup]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 3–2 {{davis|AUS}} at [[White City Stadium (Sydney)|White City Stadium]] (grass) [[Sydney]], Australia
==[[Multi-sport event]]s== * [[1954 Asian Games|Asian Games]] held in [[Manila]], the [[Philippines]] * [[1954 Central American and Caribbean Games|Central American and Caribbean Games]] held in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]] * [[Commonwealth Games|British Empire & Commonwealth Games]] held in [[Vancouver, British Columbia|Vancouver]], British Columbia
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Willie Mays]], [[Major League Baseball]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Babe Zaharias|Babe Didrikson Zaharias]], [[LPGA|LPGA golf]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} The '''2005 Canadian Paralympic Athletics Championships''' is a disabled athletics competition held in [[Regina, Saskatchewan]], Canada in 2005.
==Wheelchair Racing==
===100 m T-34 (Women's)=== *GOLD: [[Chelsea Clark]], [[Mississauga, Ontario]]
===100 m T-52 (Women's)=== *GOLD: [[Lisa Franks]], [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]]
===100 m T-53 (Men's)=== *GOLD: [[Brent Lakatos]], [[Dorval, Quebec]]: 16.20 sec
===100 m T-54 (Men's)=== *GOLD: [[Daniel Normandin]], [[Montreal]]: 15.87 sec
===100 m T-54 (Women's)=== *GOLD: [[Chantal Petitclerc]], [[Montreal]]: 18.11 sec
===5000 m T-54 (Men's)=== *GOLD: [[Jeff Adams]], [[Toronto]]: 12:14.12 *SILVER: [[Michel Filteau]], [[St-Jean-Baptiste, Quebec]]: 12:18.44
==Track and field==
===Javelin throw=== *GOLD: [[France Gagné]], [[Quebec City]]: 50.13 m
==See also== * [[Canadian Paralympic Athletics Championships]]
[[Category:Canadian Paralympics]] [[Category:2005 in Canadian sports|Canadian Paralympic Athletics Championships]] [[Category:2005 in athletics (track and field)|Canadian Paralympic Athletics Championships]]

[[File:BarCanComGames.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Barbados (blue) playing [[Canada national rugby sevens team|Canada]] (red) at the [[Rugby sevens at the 2014 Commonwealth Games|2014 Commonwealth Games]]]]
The '''Barbados national rugby sevens team''' is a minor national sevens side. They competed at the [[Rugby sevens at the Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Sevens]] in 2014. Barbados also participated in the World Series core team qualifiers at the [[2014 Hong Kong Sevens]].<ref>[http://www.irbsevens.com/mediacentre/news/newsid=2065380.html#pools+drawn+sevens+showdown+hong+kong Pools drawn for Sevens showdown in Hong Kong]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The team received some publicity in 2014, when Anthony Bayne-Charles, the son of [[Billy Ocean]], was selected to play for them as a reserve.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-2706685/Billy-Oceans-son-features-Barbados-thrashed-68-5-rugby-sevens-event-Commonwealth-Games.html Barbados call on Billy Ocean's son]</ref><ref>[http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/commonwealth-games/sevens/10316408/Billy-Oceans-son-playing-rugbys-rock-stars Billy Ocean's Son Playing Rugby's Rock Stars]</ref>
==Current squad== '''Squad to the [[2014 Hong Kong Sevens]] World Series Qualifier.<ref>http://www.irbsevens.com/matches/idcup=11040/season=2013/edition=5/gameno=6/matchDetails.html</ref> ''' *Shaun English *Marcus Harewood *Dominic Peters *Leo Donnelly *Adam Mings *Tom Lucas *Jae Bowen *Mike Phillips *Leon Driscoll *Sean Ward *Dwight Forde *Jamahl Hunte
==See also== * [[Rugby union in Barbados]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Concord Oval | nickname = | image = [[File:Concord Oval eastern grandstand.JPG|300px]] | caption = Concord Oval showing the eastern grandstand | location = [[Concord, New South Wales]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|52|6|S|151|6|34|E|type:landmark_region:AU|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1985 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[West Harbour RFC]]
[[Western Suburbs Magpies]] (1910-11, 1915-19)
[[Inter Lions SC]]
[[Wests Tigers]] (training + administration) | seating_capacity = 20,000 |}} '''Concord Oval''' (also '''Waratah Stadium''') is a [[Rugby football|rugby]] [[stadium]] in [[Concord, New South Wales|Concord]], [[Australia]], in the inner west of Sydney. It is currently used mostly for [[rugby union]] matches, and it was used for eight matches during the [[1987 Rugby World Cup]]. It also hosts [[football]] matches. The stadium is able to hold 20,000 people and was opened in 1985. It is the home ground of [[West Harbour RFC]] in the [[Shute Shield]] rugby union competition, and the [[Greater Sydney Rams]] in the [[National Rugby Championship]]. It is also the training and administration base for the [[Wests Tigers]] rugby league club. [[Football]] club [[Inter Lions SC]] also play games at the ground. ==Facilities== The stadium has two opposing grandstands. The eastern stand hosts the tennis box-style seats, television gantry and the change rooms. The stand runs approximately from try-line to try-line. The western stand contains a gym and some boxes. This stand runs approximately from dead-ball line to dead ball line. In front of the western stand are two rows of seats, while a concrete path runs around the field (except not in front of the aforementioned two rows of seats, the path runs behind those seats). At each end there is a grassy hill, and at the southern or Parramatta Road end, there is a wooden, manually operated scoreboard with an analogue clock. The stadium is bordered by Gipps Street to the north, [[Great Western Highway|Parramatta Road]] to the south, Loftus Street to the west and the Cintra Hockey Centre to the east. Parking is at a premium with small carparks behind the northern hill, eastern stand and in the south-east corner, although [[Burwood railway station, Sydney|Burwood train station]] is not too far away, and the 439, L39, 464 and 466 bus routes pass close to the stadium. ==History== St Luke's Park, which was the home ground of Sydney's [[Western Suburbs Magpies]] [[rugby league]] club in [[1910 NSWRFL season|1910]] and [[1911 NSWRFL season|1911]] was where Concord Oval is now located.{{cite web|last=westsmagpies.com.au|title=Home Grounds|url=http://www.westsmagpies.com.au/archives/000/php/venues.php|work=Wests Archives|publisher=[[Western Suburbs Magpies]]|accessdate=19 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140127020820/http://www.westsmagpies.com.au/archives/000/php/venues.php|archivedate=27 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} Wests started playing their matches at [[Pratten Park]] in 1912, but after pressure from local residents there the council refused the club permission to use that ground, forcing them to return to St. Luke's Oval from 1915 to 1919.{{cite book|last=[[Ashfield Municipal Council]]|title=Pratten Park Plan of Management|date=2008|publisher=ashfield.nsw.gov.au|location=Australia|pages=6–7|url=http://www.ashfield.nsw.gov.au/files/recreation/parks_and_reserves/plans_of_management/pom_-_pratten__park_-_april_2008.pdf}} From 1920 Wests resumed playing at Pratten Park. The stadium also hosted four first grade [[rugby league]] matches, three of them in 1994 as [[Bulldogs Rugby League Football Club|Canterbury's]] second home ground during that season. As far as high-profile events go, the stadium currently lies dormant. With the completion of the [[Sydney Football Stadium]], and later [[Stadium Australia]], the [[New South Wales Waratahs]] and [[Australia national rugby union team|Australian Wallabies]] have not played at the stadium in many years. A return is unlikely, especially considering how expansion is almost impossible due to housing to the west, roads to the north and south, and a hockey complex and canal to the east. Other issues are that the stadium does not have floodlights, a video screen, parking or modern spectator amenities. In the early 2010s the City of Canada Bay Council prepared a masterplan http://www.lpma.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/171785/Concord_Oval_draft_POM_for_public_exhibition_May_2012_version.pdf{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} to bring these events back to an expanded and rejuvenated Concord Oval. This includes construction and installation of broadcasting equipment such as satellite dishes, antennas, camera platforms and commentary boxes, as well as training quality floodlighting and a new scoreboard. Mention is made in the masterplan of attempting to lure [[Asian Football Confederation]] games to the renovated ground, however the masterplan may take up to a decade to complete. For the mean time, most events in the area prefer grounds such as [[Parramatta Stadium]], or the Olympic Park and Moore Park venues. ==Rugby World Cup== Concord Oval hosted six matches of the [[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] [[Rugby World Cup]]. {|class="wikitable" ! Date ! Competition !colspan=2| Home team !colspan=2| Away team ! Attendance |- |23 May 1987 || [[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool 1 || {{ru|AUS}} || 19 || {{ru|ENG}} || 6 || 17,896 |- |30 May 1987 || [[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool 1 || {{ru|ENG}} || 60 || {{ru|JPN}} || 7 || 4,893 |- |rowspan=2|3 June 1987 || rowspan=2|[[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool 1 || {{ru|ENG}} || 34 || {{Ru|USA}} || 6 || rowspan=2|8,785 |- | {{Ru|AUS}} || 42 || {{Ru|JPN}} || 23 |- |7 June 1987 || [[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Quarter-final 2 || {{Ru|AUS}} || 33 || {{Ru|IRE}} || 15 || 14,356 |- |13 June 1987 || [[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Semi-final 1 || {{Ru|AUS}} || 24 || {{Ru|FRA}} || 30 || 17,768 |} ==External links== *{{austadiums|39}} ==References== {{reflist}} *Rleague.com - Concord Oval [https://web.archive.org/web/20081202024502/http://www.rleague.com/db/venue/concord_oval/index.php]. {{Australian-baseball-stadiums |state=collapsed}} {{Sydney Storm |state=collapsed}} {{1987 Rugby World Cup Venues |state=collapsed}} {{NRL Grounds}} {{NRC Grounds}} [[Category:Western Suburbs Magpies]] [[Category:Rugby World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1985]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Australia]]
