{{Infobox Racecourse |Name=Monmouth Park Racetrack |Image=[[Image:MonmouthParkLogo.jpg]]|Caption=Racetrack logo |Location=175 Oceanport Ave.
[[Oceanport, New Jersey]] 07757
United States |Owner=[[New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority|NJSEA]] |Operator=Darby Development, LLC |channel=[[NBC]] (Haskell Invitational Stakes) |Opened={{start date and age|1870|July|30|p=y}} |CourseType= Flat |Website=http://www.monmouthpark.com/ |NotableRaces=[[Haskell Invitational Stakes]] (G1)
[[United Nations Stakes]] (G1)
[[Molly Pitcher Stakes]] (G2)
[[Monmouth Cup]] (G2) }} '''Monmouth Park Racetrack''' is an American [[race track]] for [[thoroughbred]] [[horse racing]] in [[Oceanport, New Jersey|Oceanport]], [[New Jersey]], United States. It is owned by the [[New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority]] and is operated under a five-year lease as a partnership with Darby Development, LLC.{{cite web|url=http://www.theracingbiz.com/2014/05/09/monmouth-park-opens-change-way-preservation|title=AS MONMOUTH PARK OPENS, CHANGE IS A WAY OF PRESERVATION|publisher=theracingbiz.com|date=May 9, 2014|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} Monmouth Park's marquee event is the [[Haskell Invitational]], named after Amory L. Haskell. The Haskell was first run in 1968 as a handicap, but was made into an Invitational Handicap in 1981. It is now a 1⅛-mile test for three-year-olds run in late July. Monmouth Park also now showcases the [[Jersey Derby]] originally run at [[Garden State Park]] until its closure in 2001. ==History== ===Long Branch Racetrack=== [[File:BreedersCupClassic2007-AwesomeGemFirstTurn.jpg|thumb|left|The racetrack and part of the stands during the [[2007 Breeders' Cup]]]] The original [[thoroughbred racing]] track was opened by the Monmouth Park Association on July 30, 1870 in [[Eatontown, New Jersey]].{{cite news |title=Inauguration of the New Monmouth Park Race-Course |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1870/07/31/archives/racing-at-the-branch-inauguration-of-the-new-monmouth-park.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 31, 1870 |page=1 |accessdate=2010-07-31}} In 1878 it was bought by [[David D. Withers]], [[George L. Lorillard]], [[James Gordon Bennett, Jr.]], and [[George P. Wetmore]]. From 1882 to 1890, the track increased in popularity, but legislation proposed in 1891 and enacted in 1894 barred [[parimutuel betting]] in [[New Jersey]], and the track closed its doors. In May 1894, the Township Committee at [[Eatontown, New Jersey]] ordered the seizure and sale of the Monmouth Park Association's [[grandstand]] and other property for the payment of back taxes and on May 7 was sold at a public auction.{{cite news |title=Monmouth Park's Troubles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1894/05/03/archives/monmouth-parks-troubles-the-grand-stand-and-personal-property-to-be.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 3, 1894 |page=3 |accessdate=2010-07-31}}{{cite news |title=Monmouth Park Effects Sold |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1894/05/08/archives/monmouth-park-effects-sold-furniture-horses-and-wagons-said-to-be.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 8, 1894 |page=3 |accessdate=2010-07-31}} Some of the major races held at the Long Branch track included the [[Champion Stakes (United States)|Champion Stakes]], the [[Freehold Stakes]], and the [[Monmouth Cup]]. The [[United States Department of the Army]] later constructed [[Fort Monmouth]] on the site of the former racetrack.{{cite web|url=http://www.fortmonmouthnj.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Concise-History-of-Fort-Monmouth.pdf||title=A Concise History of Fort Monmouth, NJ and the U.S. Army CECOM Life Cycle Management Command|publisher=FortMonmouthNJ.com|date=2009|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} ===Monmouth Park Jockey Club=== In 1946, the [[New Jersey Legislature]] passed a bill providing for state regulation of [[horse racing]]. Spurred on by [[Amory L. Haskell]], who led the legislative charge to once again permit wagering on horse racing in New Jersey and [[Philip H. Iselin]], a [[New York City]] [[textile]] magnate, along with the backing of [[Reeve Schley]], [[Joseph M. Roebling]], [[John M. MacDonald]], [[Townsend B. Martin]], and [[James Cox Brady, Jr.]]. Now called the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, it opened on June 19, 1946. [[Thoroughbred racing]] was back at the facility after a 53-year hiatus with 18,724 in attendance.{{cite news |title=Races Start Today At Monmouth Park |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1946/06/19/archives/races-start-today-at-monmouth-park-first-flight-and-mesl-among.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 19, 1946 |at=section Sports, p. 34 |accessdate=2010-07-31}} ===Monmouth Park Racetrack=== The [[New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority]] purchased Monmouth Park from its previous owners, the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, in 1985, in a deal valued at $45 million.{{cite news |title=Monmouth Park Track Sold to N.J. State Sports Agency |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PI&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB2994240168532&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=April 11, 1985 |page=B05 |accessdate=2007-10-08 |quote=The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, operator of the Meadowlands Race Track, tentatively agreed yesterday to buy Monmouth Park for about $45 million.}} The NJSEA still retains the corporate name "Monmouth Park Jockey Club".{{cite web|url=http://www.monmouthpark.com/history.aspx?id=149|title=About Monmouth Park|publisher=Monmouth Park|accessdate=July 28, 2017}} The [[Vans Warped Tour]], a touring music and [[extreme sports]] festival, was successfully held at the racetrack in 2010 and 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.last.fm/festival/1331100+Vans+Warped+Tour+2010|title=Vans Warped Tour 2010|publisher=last.fm|date=July 18, 2010|accessdate=August 2, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.last.fm/festival/1754128+Vans+Warped+Tour+2011|title=Vans Warped Tour 2011|publisher=last.fm|date=July 24, 2010|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} It marks the [[New York metropolitan area|New York]] stop on the nationwide tour, which visits the area during July. In 2012, the festival moved to the [[PNC Bank Arts Center]] in nearby [[Holmdel, New Jersey]] due to financial considerations.{{cite web|url= http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2012/07/warped_tour_changes_its_addres.html|title=Warped Tour changes its address, but little else|publisher=NJ.com|date=July 13, 2012|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} In 2011, a five-year lease was signed with Morris Bailey, co-owner of [[Resorts Casino Hotel]] in Atlantic City, to provide a marketing partnership between the casino and racetrack. The agreement allowed Resorts to sponsor the Haskell Invitational, and possibilities include a merging of loyalty programs as well as bringing entertainers' appearances at the casino to the racetrack. The program is part of a strategy to mesh horse racing with casino gambling.{{cite web |url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/communities/atlantic-city_pleasantville_brigantine/resorts-casino-hotel-gets-business-partner-in-monmouth-park/article_b0c8a370-b648-11e0-b5cd-001cc4c002e0.html |title=Resorts Casino Hotel gets business partner in Monmouth Park |work=[[Press of Atlantic City]] |author=Donald Wittkowski |date=24 Jul 2011 |accessdate=25 Jul 2011}} In April 2013, Monmouth Park opened the Bluegrass [[Miniature Golf]] Course near the Port-au-Peck Ave. entrance. The Course features two 18-hole courses, the Haskell Course and the [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing (United States)|Triple Crown]] Course.{{cite web|url=http://www.monmouthpark.com/event_detail.aspx?id=7083|title=Bluegrass Miniature Golf OPENS|publisher=Monmouth Park|date=April 27, 2013|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} In July 2016, the luxury restaurant Blu Grotto, named after the [[Blue Grotto (Capri)|Blue Grotto]] [[sea cave]] on the Italian island of [[Capri]], opened at Monmouth Park. The restaurant is open year-round and is located near the racetrack's quarter-pole.{{cite web|url=http://www.thoroughbreddailynews.com/luxury-restaurant-added-to-monmouth-menu/|title=Luxury Restaurant Added to Monmouth Menu|publisher=Thoroughbred Daily News|date=July 27, 2016|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} The [[Beer garden|Beer Garden]] at Blu Grotto opened in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.monmouthpark.com/content.aspx?id=8072||title=Blu Grotto|publisher=Monmouth Park|date=August 2, 2017}} ==Physical Attributes== {{unreferenced section|date=June 2014}} The main track is a one-mile (1.6 km) dirt oval with chutes for 6 furlong and 1¼ mile races. [[File:Monmouth turf.jpg|thumb|The long infield chute at Monmouth Park leads to the main turf course and allows for races of up to 1⅛ miles.]] The [[grass|turf]] course is seven furlongs in circumference, with a diagonal chute for races between {{convert|1|mi|km|adj=on}} and 1⅛ miles. A re-design of the grass course for the 2006 season brought with it a new, second chute to accommodate 5½ furlong sprint races. Turf races can be run along the hedge, or with the portable rail out 12 feet (dubbed the "Haskell Course"), 24 feet ("Monmouth Course") or 36 feet ("Lennox Course"). The Stable Area, located directly to the north of the back stretch of the main track, contains a total of forty barns and stables, twelve north of the [[New Jersey Transit]]'s [[North Jersey Coast Line]] (connected by its own service and access road) and twenty eight on the main complex. The Wolf Hill Farm, which served Monmouth Park as a private stable and practice facility, is located adjacent to and immediately west of the main complex. Wolf Hill, owned and operated by the Valentino Family from the nearby City of [[Long Branch, New Jersey]] featured barns, stables and a practice track featuring a dirt oval and turf course identical to that at Monmouth Park's main facility only built to 50% scale. The Valentino Family sold Wolf Hill Farm to the [[Monmouth Park Jockey Club]] in 1963 which then became part of the greater Monmouth Park Complex. It was transferred to state ownership in the 1986 takeover by the NJSEA and was eventually sold to the [[Monmouth County Park System]] in 1998 which now operates the site as Wolf Hill Recreation Area that features a 4-acre [[dog park]], an 18-hole [[disc golf]] course, a [[baseball field]] and two [[softball]] fields.{{cite web|url=https://www.monmouthcountyparks.com/page.aspx?ID=2548|title=Wolf Hill Recreation Area|publisher=Monmouth County Parks|date=August 2, 2017}} While Wolf Hill ceased operating as a farm following the 1963 sale, owners and trainers continued to use Wolf Hill's practice track well into the 1990s. Remnants of the practice were clearly visible on the site until after the 2009 meet. After the 2009 meet, construction began in the Wolf Hill area, eliminating the last of the practice track.{{cite web|url=http://www.pdga.com/course-directory/course/wolf-hill-recreation-area-disc-golf|title=Wolf Hill Recreation Area Disc Golf|publisher=Professional Disc Golf Association|date=August 2, 2017}} ==Racing== [[File:Monmouth Park racing on June 4, 2011.jpg|thumb|300px|Horse racing at Monmouth Park]] *[[Graded stakes race|Grade 1:]] **[[Haskell Invitational Handicap]] **[[United Nations Stakes]] *Grade 2: **[[Molly Pitcher Stakes]] **[[Monmouth Cup]] *Grade 3: **[[Boiling Springs Stakes]] ([[grass|Turf]]) **[[Cliff Hanger Stakes]] **[[Eatontown Handicap]] **[[Jersey Shore Breeders' Cup Stakes]] **[[Long Branch Stakes]] **[[Matchmaker Stakes]] **[[Monmouth Oaks]] **[[Monmouth Stakes]] **[[Oceanport Stakes]] **[[Pegasus Stakes]] **[[Philip H. Iselin Stakes]] **[[Red Bank Stakes|Red Bank Handicap]] **[[Salvator Mile Handicap]] **[[Violet Stakes]] *Ungraded stakes **[[Colleen Stakes]] **[[Dan Horn Stakes]] **[[Lady's Secret Stakes (Monmouth Park)|Lady's Secret Stakes]] **[[Longfellow Stakes]] **[[Miss Woodford Stakes]] **[[Jersey Derby]] **[[Lamplighter Stakes]] **[[Majestic Light Stakes]] **[[Monmouth Beach Stakes]] **[[Monmouth Regret Stakes|Regret Stakes]] **[[Mr. Prospector Stakes]] **[[Rumson Stakes]] **[[Sapling Stakes]] **[[Tyro Stakes]] ===Breeders' Cup World Championships=== On October 26 and 27, 2007, Monmouth Park hosted the [[Breeders' Cup]] for the first time in its history.{{cite news |title=Curlin Is Favorite for Haskell |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/03/sports/othersports/03sportsbriefs-haskell.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=August 3, 2007 |accessdate=2007-10-08 |quote=It is a pivotal one-and-one-eighth-mile race for 3-year-olds with the Breeders’ Cup World Championships being held at Monmouth for the first time Oct. 26-27.}}
The 2007 Event also marked the first time the event has been held over two days and also the creation of three new races held on Day 1 of the Championships. '''Winners of Races''':
'''Day 1'''
Filly & Mare Sprint-[[Maryfield (horse)|Maryfield]]
Juvenile Turf-[[Nownownow]]
Dirt Mile-[[Corinthian (horse)|Corinthian]]
'''Day 2'''
Juvenile Fillies-[[Indian Blessing]]
Juvenile-[[War Pass]]
Filly & Mare Turf-[[Lahudood]]
Sprint-[[Midnight Lute]]
Mile-[[Kip Deville]]
Distaff-[[Ginger Punch]]
Turf-[[English Channel]]
Classic-[[Curlin]] The Classic was marred by a fatal injury suffered by George Washington, the 2006 European 3-year-old champion who had returned to training when his stud career was scuttled by fertility problems. He suffered a dislocated fracture of his right front ankle and was euthanized on the track. ===Million Dollar Meet=== In March 2010, it was announced that Monmouth Park would shorten its summer meet, conducting only 50 days of live racing (down from 141 total [[thoroughbred]] days in the state) for a total of $50 million in purse money for the 2010 meet. This was done due to the recent monetary losses of the racetrack industry in New Jersey and made it the most expensive purse structure in North America at the time. ==TV Personalites== *Caton Bredar (1995–1998) *Barbara Foster (1995–1997) *Jennifer Burke (2000–2004) *Carolyn Conley *Brad Thomas (?-present) *Thomas Cassidy (?-present) *[[Larry Collmus]] (1994–2014) *Mike Curci *Gordon Richards *Matt Carothers (1998) *Travis Stone (2014) ==TV & Film Appearances== *The track appears in the 1984 film classic ''[[The Pope of Greenwich Village]]''. *Monmouth Park was featured in a 1986 episode of ''[[The Equalizer|The Equalizer TV series]]'', entitled "Tip on a Sure Thing." *''[[Law & Order]]'' filmed an episode at Monmouth Park racetrack entitled "Sport of Kings" in 2005. *The 2010 film ''[[The Bounty Hunter (2010 film)|The Bounty Hunter]]'' starring Jennifer Aniston and Gerard Butler filmed a brief scene at Monmouth Park. *The track was briefly shown on an episode of ''[[Impractical Jokers]]''. ==Accessibility & transportation== The Park is served by the [[Monmouth Park station|Monmouth Park]] station on [[New Jersey Transit]]'s [[North Jersey Coast Line]] during the racing season.{{cite web|url=http://www.monmouthpark.com/content.aspx?id=245|title=By Train|publisher=Monmouth Park|accessdate=July 28, 2017}} A special train called the "Pony Express" was discontinued after the 2005 racing season. This train operated between [[Hoboken Terminal]] and the racetrack, terminating on a rail siding near the grandstand entrance. It was often scouted out by [[railfan]]s due to the variety of equipment that were used on the train in recent years, ranging from the 1970 vintage [[Pullman Standard]] [[Erie Lackawanna]] Comet I cars to modern Alstom [[Metro-North]] Comet Vs. Monmouth Park is also served by the [[List of New Jersey Transit bus routes (800-880)|831]] [[New Jersey Transit Bus Operations|New Jersey Transit Bus]] route.{{cite web|url=http://www.njtransit.com/pdf/bus/T0831.pdf|title=831 Schedule|publisher=NJ Transit|date=September 3, 2016|accessdate=July 28, 2017}} The Park is accessible by car via [[New Jersey Route 36|NJ-36]] with connections to the [[Garden State Parkway]], [[Interstate 195 (New Jersey)|I-195]], [[New Jersey Turnpike]] ([[Interstate 95 in New Jersey|I-95]]) and other highways and roads. Parking is available in several on site lots.{{cite web|url=http://www.monmouthpark.com/directions.aspx?Id=94|title=By Car|publisher=Monmouth Park|date=July 28, 2017}} ==See also== *[[Gambling in New Jersey]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Monmouth Park Racetrack}} * [http://www.monmouthpark.com Monmouth Park Racetrack] * [http://www.nj-horse.com New Jersey Horse Enthusiast Web] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080115023918/http://www.njhorseonline.com/ New Jersey Horse Online] * [http://www.gate2wire.com/index.php/2009/08/monmouth-park-racetrack-review Gate2Wire Review] * [http://colinsghost.org/2010/05/the-original-monmouth-park-1870-and-1890.html The Original Monmouth Parks, 1870 and 1890] {{coord|40|18|34.85|N|74|0|52.15|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:1870 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Gambling in New Jersey]] [[Category:Horse racing venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Monmouth County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Monmouth County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Monmouth Park Racetrack| ]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1870]]

{{no footnotes|date=September 2014}} {{infobox martial art | logo = | logocaption = | logosize = | image = Laocolonialpicture.jpg | imagecaption = Muay Lao boxers training during the colonial period | imagesize =150px | name = Muay Lao | aka = Lao boxing, Lao kickboxing | focus = [[Strike (attack)|Striking]] | hardness = [[Full contact sport|Full contact]] | country = {{flagicon|Laos}} [[Laos]] | creator = | parenthood = [[Muay Boran]] | famous_pract = | olympic = No | website = }} '''Muay Lao ({{lang-lo|ມວຍລາວ}})''' is a traditional unarmed [[martial art]] from [[Laos]]. It is similar to [[muay Thai]] from [[Thailand]], [[pradal serey]] from [[Cambodia]], and [[tomoi]] from [[Malaysia]]. It incorporates punches, kicks, elbows and knee strikes. Muay Lao was an event at the [[2009 Southeast Asian Games]] in [[Vientiane]].
The martial art is related to other forms of martial arts found in other parts of the [[Greater India|Indian cultural sphere]] including [[Musti-yuddha]] in India, [[Muay Thai]] in Thailand, [[Pradal serey]] in Cambodia and [[Lethwei]] in Myanmar.
==See also== *[[Lethwei]] *[[Muay Boran]] *[[Muay Thai]] *[[Pradal Serey]] *[[Tomoi]]
==External links== *[http://www.vientianetimes.org.la/Sports/Sport_Borikhamxay%27s.htm Vientiane Times] *[http://www.vientianetimes.org.la/Sports/Sport_provincial.htm Vientiane Times-Provincial kick-boxers challenge city counterparts] *[https://www.vietnamroyaltourism.com/Laos-Travel-Guide/The-Culture/muay-lao-lao-boxing.html Vietnam Royal Tourism]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[http://www.vientianetimes.org.la/Sports/Sport_former.htm Former national kick-boxer returns for Vientiane event] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=qkuSVaUuiVgC&pg=PT42 Laos in pictures] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lLlf225B6W8 Lao boxing video] *[http://www.goabroad.net/Brooklynmonk/journals/1197/Muay-Lao,-the-forgotten-art-of-kickboxing ''Muay Lao, the forgotten art of kickboxing'' - from GoAbroad.net]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Nexhip Trungu Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | fullname = Nexhip Trungu Stadium | former_names = | location = [[Cërrik]], [[Albania]] | coordinates = {{Coord|41|01|49|N|19|59|38.8|E|type:landmark_region:AL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | home team = [[KF Turbina Cërrik|Turbina Cërrik]] | built = | opened = | reconstructed = | owner = Turbina Cërrik
[[Cërrik |Cërrik Municipality]] | operator = Turbina Cërrik | construction_cost = | surface = [[Grass|Natural grass]] | scoreboard = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_capacity = 6,600 | dimensions = | Suites = | record_attendance = | website = }} '''Nexhip Trungu Stadium''' ({{lang-sq|Stadiumi Nexhip Trungu}}) is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Cërrik]], [[Elbasan County]], [[Albania]] which is used as the home ground of local football club [[KF Turbina Cërrik|Turbina Cërrik]].[https://int.soccerway.com/venues/albania/stadiumi-nexhip-trungu/v4808/ Soccerway profile] In 2015 Turbina Cërrik were promoted to the [[Albanian First Division]], the second tier of Albanian football, and Cërrik Municipality made minor improvements to the stadium which included the installation of 350 new seats in the main stand as well as a renovation of the changing rooms. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nexhip Trungu Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in Albania]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Elbasan]] [[Category:Sport in Elbasan]] {{Albania-sports-venue-stub}} {{Football venues in Albania}}

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Papoose Peak Jumps | nickname = | image = [[File:Papoose Peak ski jumping hill Squaw-Valley, California.jpg|250px]] | caption = | location = Little Papoose Peak | city = [[Squaw Valley Ski Resort|Squaw Valley]] | country = [[United States]] | opened = 1958 | renovated = 1975 | expanded = | closed = 1976 | demolished = Yes | size = 80/60/40 | k-spot = K80 | hill size = K80, K60, K40 | hill record = [[Jim Denney (ski jumper born 1957)|Jim Denney]]
(99.0 m in 1976) | championships = | olympics = [[1960 Winter Olympics|1960]] | world championships = | national championships = 1976 US National Ski Jumping Championships }} '''Papoose Peak Jumps''' was a [[ski jumping hill]] located at [[Squaw Valley Ski Resort]] in the US state of [[California]]. The hill consisted of three jumps, with [[K-point]]s of 80, 60 and 40 meters, respectively. Constructed upon the hill-side of Little Papoose Peak, it was built for the [[1960 Winter Olympics]]; the 80-meter hill hosted the [[ski jumping at the 1960 Winter Olympics|ski jumping event]] and the 60-meter hill the [[Nordic combined at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined event]]. The jump was designed by [[Heini Klopfer]] and opened in 1958. After the Olympics the venue saw little use; it was renovated for the 1976 US National Ski Jumping Championships, but has since fallen into disrepair and demolished to make room for a [[ski lift]]. ==History== As Squaw Valley was an undeveloped area when it was awarded the Olympics, the organizing committee was free to design a tailor-made Olympic resort.Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 33 Heini Klopfer from [[Oberstdorf]], West Germany, was hired to design the ski jumping hills, which he finished in early 1957. He chose to locate it on the hill-side of Little Papoose Peak, opposite [[Blyth Arena]]. He described the location as "the type of hill one always seeks but seldom finds".Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 103 The construction contract was awarded to Diversified Builders, who constructed the jumps during the summer and fall of 1958. Papoose Peak Jumps was the first Olympic ski jump to have three [[ski jump|in-runs]]. Minor details were corrected in 1959 and 1960. It was renovated ahead of the 1976 US National Championships.{{cite web |url=http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/EN/Ski+Jumps/USA-United+States/CA-California/Squaw+Valley/0578/ |title=Papoose Peak Jumps |publisher=Ski Jumping Hill Archive |accessdate=21 June 2012 |archivedate=21 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68aoW89n1?url=http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/EN/Ski+Jumps/USA-United+States/CA-California/Squaw+Valley/0578/ |deadurl=no |df= }} However, it fell out of use afterwards and instead the hill was converted to a [[speed skiing]] and [[snowboarding]] hill. Later the resort's Far East Express chairlift was installed on the hill.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1960/SKJ/ |title=Ski Jumping at the 1960 Squaw Valley Winter Games |publisher=Sports Reference |accessdate=21 June 2012 |archivedate=21 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68aoaPS0M?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1960/SKJ/ |deadurl=no |df= }} ==Facilities== The hill consisted of three jumps with a common out-run, each with a [[construction point]] (K-point) of 80, 60 and 40 meters, respectively. It was located in the central area of the Olympic resort, next to the skating rinks and the Olympic Village. Tall trees on both sides of the hill gave good protection against the wind. The location was also ideal because of the sun was at the competitor's backs. A judges' tower was constructed on the side, which was both accessible by stairs from the bottom of the hill or from the chairlift which ran to the top of the in-runs. The hill had an overall height of {{convert|140|m|sp=us}}, the in-run had a length of {{convert|113|m|sp=us}}. The largest jump had a take-off angle of 8.5 degrees and a landing angle of 38 degrees. ==Events== The first competitive use of the hills was the trial Olympics in February 1959. During the 1960 Winter Olympics, the 80-meter hill was used for special jumping on 28 February,Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 105 while the 60-meter hill was used for Nordic combined on 22 February.Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 106 The [[ski jumping at the 1960 Winter Olympics|special ski jumping event]] was won by [[Helmut Recknagel]] of [[Germany at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Germany]], who also set a hill record of {{convert|93.5|m|sp=us}}. He was followed up by [[Finland at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Finland]]'s [[Niilo Halonen]] and [[Austria at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Austria]]'s [[Otto Leodolter]]. In the ski jumping part of the [[Nordic combined at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined event]], Germany's [[Georg Thoma]] received the highest points ahead of the [[Soviet Union at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Soviet Union]]'s [[Dmitriy Kochkin]] and [[Norway at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Norway]]'s [[Tormod Knutsen]]. The cross-country part of the event took place at [[McKinney Creek Stadium]].Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 110 While Thoma won the discipline overall, Knutsen finished second overall ahead of the Soviet Union's [[Nikolai Gusakov]]. In 1976, the US National Championships in Ski Jumping were held at the large hill, and was won by [[Jim Denney (ski jumper born 1957)|Jim Denney]]. ==References== ;Bibliography * {{cite book |last1=Squaw Valley Organizing Committee|title=VIII Olympic Winter Games Squaw Valley, California 1960 Final Report |publisher=California Olympic Commission|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1960/1960w.pdf |format=PDF |year=1960 |location=Squaw Valley |accessdate=20 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629132958/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1960/1960w.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2011 |deadurl=no}} ;Notes {{reflist}} {{coord|39.194004|-120.231012|type:landmark_region:US|format=dms|display=title}} {{1960 Winter Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues Nordic combined}} {{Olympic venues in ski jumping}} [[Category:Ski jumping venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Placer County, California]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in California]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Placer County, California]] [[Category:Venues of the 1960 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic Nordic combined venues]] [[Category:Olympic ski jumping venues]] [[Category:1958 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]]

[[File:Two pasikings.JPG|alt=Two pasikings|thumb|Pasikings are made in various sizes and finished with either a natural or dark color.]] The '''''pasiking''''' (English term:'''knapbasket'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://anthro.upd.edu.ph/beyer-museum-online-exhibit/152-pasiking |title=Pasiking |website=[[University of the Philippines Diliman]] |publisher=UPD Department of Anthropology |access-date=28 October 2015}}</ref>) is the indigenous basket-backpack found among the various ethno-linguistic groups of [[Northern Luzon]] in the [[Philippines]]. Pasiking designs have sacred allusions, although most are purely aesthetic. These artifacts, whether handwoven traditionally or with contemporary variations, are considered exemplars of functional basketry in the Philippines and among [[Filipinos]].<ref>The [http://www.google.com.ph/search?aq=f&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&q=pasiking NCI SF homepage] on pasiking.com</ref>
[[File:Vicente4.jpg|thumb|A [[Manilan]] sporting a centuries-old variant of the Northern Philippine pasiking.|left]]The ritual pasiking of the [[Ifugao people#The Ifugao|Ifugao tribal group]] is called the ''inabnutan'', not to be confused with the more common ''bangeo''. Both of those types have palm bast weatherproofing.
The ritual pasiking of the [[Igorot#The Bontoc|Bontoc people]] is called the ''takba,'' and represents an ancestor figure, and active participant in ''begnas'' rituals.
Some of the Northern Philippine tribal groups called [[Igorots]] or Cordillerans<ref>Blog on the [http://ivegotmail.blogspot.com/2004/11/pasiking.html Igorots], plus a photo of an Igorot ''pasiking''</ref> that weave pasiking are the [[Apayaos]] or [[Isneg]], the [[Tinguian]] of [[Abra (province)|Abra]] province, the [[Igorot#The Kalinga|Kalingas]] of [[Kalinga (province)|Kalinga]] province, the Gaddang, the Bugkalot, the Applai, the [[Igorot#The Bontoc|Bontocs]] of [[Bontoc, Mountain Province]], the Ilagod, the Bago, the [[Igorot#The Kankanaey|Kankana-ey]], the [[Balangao]], the [[Ibaloi]], the [[Ifugao people#The Ifugao|Ifugaos]], the Ikalahan, the Kalanguya, the Karao, and the Ilongots. It is also woven using [[rattan]] by non-Cordilleran persons.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gascon |first=Melvin |date=27 May 2015 |title=Blind weaver’s masterpiece a tribute to Ifugao heritage |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/693795/blind-weavers-masterpiece-a-tribute-to-ifugao-heritage |newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |location=Philippines |access-date=28 October 2015 }}</ref>
Common materials used in construction are rattan and bamboo. There are pasiking specimens utilizing deer hide (parfleche), wood, turtle shell, and crocodile skin.
A deconstructed version of the pasiking, including dozens of variants, were exhibited in the [[Benedicto Cabrera|BenCab]] Museum.<ref>{{cite news |date=15 December 2014 |title=Gallery News: ‘Carrier of Tradition: An Exhibition of Northern Philippine Backpacks’ at BenCab Museum |url=http://www.philstar.com/arts-and-culture/2014/12/15/1402209/gallery-news-carrier-tradition-exhibition-northern-philippine |newspaper=[[The Philippine Star]] |location=Philippines |access-date=28 October 2015 }}</ref> There are also 21st century pasiking that are made of recyclable materials like plastic cargo straps, canvas conveyor belts, and recycled detonation cord.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lolarga |first=Elizabeth |date=21 May 2012 |title=Cool everyday objects bridge old, new in the Cordillera |url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/48955/cool-everyday-objects-bridge-old-new-in-the-cordillera |newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |location=Philippines |access-date=28 October 2015 }}</ref>
In the 1970s on through the 1980s, the pasiking has also been a symbol among Filipino students for nationalist activism. There was a decline of making traditional bamboo crafts, including the pasiking, during the 1980s but in the mid-2010s, the industry of bamboo crafts came into resurgence with the help of the Philippines' [[Department of Trade and Industry (Philippines)|Department of Trade and Industry]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Beleo |first=Erwin |date=26 November 2014 |title=Resurgent bamboo craft industry in far-flung village |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/resurgent-bamboo-craft-industry-in-far-flung-village/ |newspaper=[[Manila Bulletin]] |location=Philippines |access-date=28 October 2015 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Motorsport venue |Name =Pike's Peak International Raceway |Nicknames = |Time = |Location =16650 Midway Ranch Road, Fountain, Colorado, 80817 |Coordinates = {{coord|38|35|29.85|N|104|40|34.39|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |Image =[[File:PPIRlogo.JPG|250px]]
[[File:Pikes Peak International Raceway.png|250px]] |Image_caption = |capacity_type = Grandstand capacity
Maximum for facility |Capacity =10,000
40,000{{r|Amenities}} |Designer = Fink, Roberts & Petrie (construction began May 1996){{r|Sommer1997}} |Owner =Pikes Peak International Raceway, LLC |Opened =1997 |Construction_cost=$50 million |Events =''[[USAC Silver Crown Series]] |Layout1 =Oval & Road Course |Surface =Asphalt |Length_km =1.61 |Length_mi =1.00 |Turns =4 |Banking =10° |Record_time = |Record_driver = |Record_team = |Record_year = |Record_class = |Layout2 =Road Course |Surface2 =Asphalt |Length_km2 =2.09 |Length_mi2 =1.30 |Turns2 =9 |Banking2 =varying |Record_time2 = |Record_driver2 = |Record_team2 = |Record_year2 = |Record_class2 = |Layout3 =Short Oval |Surface3 =Asphalt |Length_km3 =0.40 |Length_mi3 =0.25 |Turns3 =4 |Banking3 = |Record_time3 = |Record_driver3 = |Record_team3 = |Record_year3 = |Record_class3 = |Miles_first = True }} '''Pikes Peak International Raceway''' ('''PPIR''') is a racetrack in a [[Colorado Springs]] annexed area of the [[Fountain, Colorado]], postal zone that by October 12, 1997, was "the fastest 1-mile paved oval anywhere".{{Cite news |last=Bergsten |first=Tim |date=October 12, 1997 |title=PPIR races through 1st year, tunes up for next |newspaper=[[The Gazette (Colorado Springs)|The Gazette]] |quote=Myers, and Apollo Real Estate Advisory of New York, the track's co-owners, didn't borrow money to build PPIR. Neither has a loan to pay.}} The speedway hosted races in several series including the [[Indy Racing League]] and 2 [[NASCAR]] series ([[Nationwide Series|Busch]] and [[Camping World Truck Series|Truck]]) until operations were suspended 2005–08. A wide variety of amateur racing groups use PPIR for racing and training, and many NASCAR teams use PPIR for testing.{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}} ==History== Racing in the [[Pikes Peak Region]] included 19th century horse tracks (e.g., to the west of Colorado Springs' [[Antlers Hotel (Colorado)|Palmer House]] along [[Fountain Creek (Arkansas River)|Fountain Creek]] by 1882{{Cite map |year=1882 |title=Panoramic Bird's Eye View of Colorado Springs, Colorado City & Manitou, Colo. |url=https://www.loc.gov/item/75693126 |publisher=J. J. Stoner, Madison, Wis. ("Beck & Paul, Lithographers, Milwaukee") |quote=Palmer House…Cascade [across from end of] Pikes Peak}} (image link to the [[Library of Congress]]) and to the north by 1903, the "[[Roswell, Colorado|Roswell Racing Park]]"),{{Cite book |type=almanac |date=May 1903 |title=The Giles City Directory of Colorado Springs and Manitou |url=http://more.ppld.org:8080/specialCollections/Index/ArticleOrders/ColoradoSpringsCityDirectories/1903CSCityDirectory.pdf |publisher=The Giles Directory Company |accessdate=2013-11-02 |quote=}} '''Chapters''': The Giles Classified Business Directory of Colorado Springs [p. 559] … of Colorado City [p. 715] … of Manitou [p. 755] and the annual [[Pikes Peak International Hill Climb]] started in 1916 on the 1915 [[Pikes Peak Highway]]. In 1938, a track was north of [[Alexander Aircraft Company|the Alexander Aircraft factory]] and {{circa|lk=no|[[World War II]]}} another was to the factory's southeast at the south end of the [[Nichols Field (airport)|Nichols Field]] taxiway.{{Cite web |last=Freeman |first=Paul |date=2013-10-13 |title=Colorado Springs area |url=http://www.airfields-freeman.com/CO/Airfields_CO_ColoradoSprings.htm#alexander |publisher=airfields-freeman.com|accessdate=2013-11-17 |quote=}} On the [[U.S. Route 24 in Colorado|Pike's Peak Ocean-to-Occan Highway]]{{r|Directory1916}} west of the city was the end of the 1951 Colorado sports car rally (terminus at the [[Crystola, Colorado|Crystola Inn]]),{{r|RoadTrack1951}} a 1953 dirt [[dragstrip]] "some four miles east of Colorado Springs" was used for "the first statewide drag race",{{Cite journal |last=Southworth |first=Bill |title=Colorado Conquest |journal= |quote=…through the efforts of the local Sea-Bee Reserve unit… Grading equipment was loaned by Douglas Jardine, a Colorado Springs contractor and commander of the unit. … president of the Cam Winders [club] "Our goal is to make Colorado Springs the mecca of all hot rodders in the Rocky Mountain area [by having] the strip paved…}} and a stock car track was along Powers Road in the early 1960s. The "last local track" for auto racing east of the city through the late 1970s was the '''Colorado Springs International Speedway''' which "had crowds in the 3,000-4,000 range on summer weekends".{{Cite news |last=Routon |first=Ralph |date=May 29, 1997 |title=No telling how many will attend first races |newspaper=The Gazette}} The Platte Avenue go-kart track closed {{circa|lk=no|1990}}, the greyhound track closed {{circa|lk=no|2005}} and is now an off track betting facility, and the [[List of cycling tracks and velodromes#USA|Olympic velodrome]] in [[Memorial Park, Colorado Springs|Memorial Park]] is a remaining racing venue within the city. ===Pikes Peak Meadows=== '''Pikes Peak Meadows''' was a dirt horse racing track facility opened in 1964{{r|Hartman1997}} {{convert|20|mi|abbr=on}} south of [[Colorado Springs]] and {{convert|25|mi|abbr=on}} north of [[Pueblo, Colorado]], with a large, blue, covered grandstand on the west. The facility was annexed by the [[City of Colorado Springs]] {{circa|lk=no|1985}}{{Cite news |last=Hartman |first=Todd |date=April 6, 1997 |title=Raceways neighbors feeling run over |newspaper=[[Gazette Telegraph]] |quote=Residents found out about the racetrack plans in early 1996. Rancher [Kirk] Hanna immediately flew [[Phoenix International Speedway|to Phoenix to record noise from a racetrack there]] … The city originally annexed the site in the mid-1980s to capture the benefits of a horse racing track.}} and after its horse racing ended in 1993, the city "approved the speedway in January 1996".{{Cite news |last=Hartman |first=Todd |date=June 1, 1997 |title=Raceway promoters face ghosts of horse track's past failure |newspaper=The Gazette |quote=… the former horse track … closed for good in 1993 … dirt horse racing track built in 1964 … [[C. C. Myers|Clinton Charles Myers]] himself came from California to visit the site with O'Sullivan in 1995. … The raceway now owns 1,000 acres. … The City Council approved the speedway in January 1996.}} [[C. C. Myers]] "announced plans in May 1996 to build a major auto racing facility" at Pikes Peak Meadows.{{Cite news |last=Bergsten |first=Tim |date=June 1, 1997 |title=Start your engines -- racing begins Saturday |newspaper=The Gazette |quote=In July, Michael Waltrip and Kenny Schrader … will race in the Winston West 500K race at PPIR. When Myers announced plans in May 1996 to build a major auto racing facility here, fans and business people could not believe their good fortune. … In 1994, Myers received national recognition for rebuilding the earthquake-ravaged Santa Monica Freeway 74 days ahead of schedule.}} ===Speedway development=== In 1997, "[[Apollo Real Estate Advisors]] LP formed a joint venture January 30 with Raceway Associates, a partnership headed by California contractor and developer C.C. Myers Inc, to own and run the 1,300-acre" speedway complex.{{Cite news |last=Hellman |first=Wayne |title=Investors buy into race track |newspaper=Gazette Telegraph }} The asphalt track was constructed {{Convert|6|ft|abbr=on}} below the "normal ground level",{{Cite news |last=Bergsten |first=Tim |title=Completion of raceway on track for summer |newspaper=The Gazette |quote=Most of the bleacher structure that will seat 42,700 is in place … The bleachers wrap around the west side of the track, which was sunk 6 feet below the normal ground level to improve viewing.}} C.C. Myers planned "to get a big-time NASCAR race in 1998",{{Cite news |last=Routon |first=Ralph |date=April 13, 1997 |title=Rising steel eye-opener along I-25 |newspaper=The Gazette}} and the facility had an open house for the local community on May 31, 1997.{{Cite news |last=Bergsten |first=Tim |date=May 28, 1997 |title=Countdown begins at new track |newspaper=The Gazette |quote=Anyone interested in having a closeup look at the track can take a free tour this weekend.}} The first race's attendance (June 8) was 16,810,{{Cite web |title=Pikes Peak International Raceway |url=http://www.nascar.com/races/tracks/pik/index.html |publisher=NASCAR.com |accessdate=}}{{Verify source|date=December 2013}} the Richard Petty Driving Experience used PPIR July 2–17,{{r|Bergsten1997}} the first IRL Series race on June 28 was televised, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xN2ih-Lmirk 1997 IRL Race TV Broadcast and a [[Winston West]] 500K race was held in July 1997.{{Cite news |last=Bergsten |first=Tim |date=June 11, 1997 |title=Petty's racing school not for Sunday drivers |newspaper=The Gazette}} ===International Speedway Corporation=== [[File:Pikes Peak International Raceway 2018.JPG|275px|thumb|right|The stands and part of the infield, viewed from the south]] Earlier in 1996, a competing track near Denver in [[Adams County, Colorado]] was attempted by [[Penske Corporation|Penske Motorsports, Inc.]] which merged in 1999 with the [[International Speedway Corporation]].{{r|Jayski}} In 2002 ISC gained "the right of first refusal should PPIR owners decide to sell their 1,200-acre complex"{{r|Jayski}} and in October 2005 for $11 million,{{Cite news |last=Bainbridge |first=Jim |date=November 23, 2006 |title=PPIR may become a private racetrack |newspaper=The Gazette }} "bought out the owners of Pikes Peak International Raceway"{{r|Jayski}} (racing operations were suspended and the scoreboard was moved to [[Texas Motor Speedway]].) In 2006, meetings "between attorneys representing [Commerce City, near Denver] and International Speedway Corporation"{{r|Jayski}} were conducted before ISC "announced in February [1997] that it was eyeing land in [[Commerce City]] as well as eastern Aurora for the track. It envision[ed] a $360 million to $400 million track and stadium that could hold 75,000 to 80,000 fans."{{r|Jayski}} A new opposition group, Commerce City Citizens and Business Alliance, endorsed anti-raceway candidates which won local elections, and in May 1997 "ISC executive Wesley Harris said the 1,300-acre parcel the company was considering near Denver International Airport was not compatible with its needs".{{r|Jayski}} ISC sold PPIR in November 2006 (the purchase closed in the first quarter of 2007),{{r|Bainbridge2006}} and PPIR operations resumed in 2008. ===Current races=== On December 6, 2012, [[United States Auto Club|USAC]] announced that PPIR would be on the 2013 [[USAC Silver Crown Series|USAC Traxxas Silver Crown Series]] schedule.[http://www.usacracing.com/silvercrown_index/news_sc/5853.html 2013 Silver Crown Schedule] Pikes Peak International Raceway would host the richest event in [[SRL Southwest Tour]] history as announced on April 23, 2013.http://www.srlsouthwesttour.com/pikes-peak-international-raceway-to-host-richest-event-in-spears-southwest-tour-history/ PPIR also hosts regional club road course races such as the National Auto Sport Association (NASA) and SCCA as well as local enthusiast events such as track days, drifting events, and car shows. ===Race results=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ PPIR race winners |- ! {{refimprove|date=October 2017}} [[File:Running-shorts-black.png|thumb|200px|right|Black running shorts]] '''Running shorts''' are a specialized form of [[shorts]] worn by [[Running|runners]].
== Materials == Running shorts are designed to facilitate comfort and free movement during exercise. Their materials are lightweight and hard-wearing. Many running shorts include an inner lining that acts as underwear, so wearing separate underwear is not necessary. [[Polyester]] is a common fabric in running shorts.
== Variants == [[File:Ludovic and Lauren (8425515069).jpg|thumb|[[Marathon]] runners in running shorts]]
Many running shorts have a seam cut up the side of each leg to enable freer movement. Manufacturers define running shorts according to the length of the leg which is not cut. For example, a 3/4 seam means that 1/4 of the length is cut.
<!-- (Commenting this out until the issue is resolved.) * "Full split shorts" are [shortest/longest - needs definition]--> * 1/2 split seam shorts are the shortest. * 3/4 split seam shorts are short, but not as short as 1/2 split seam shorts. * Square leg shorts have no split at all.
Longer shorts are not ideal for running. A runner's stride may pull up the shorts' fabric, which can cause discomfort. Nonetheless, some runners prefer longer shorts because they cover a greater portion of their legs.
Some runners use athletic [[hot pants]] as running shorts. Like 1/2 split seam shorts, hot pants do not encumber leg movement.
[[Lycra]] running shorts are an alternative to conventional, polyester-based shorts. In most cases, they reach the mid-thigh. They are skin-tight, so they allow for more flexible, unencumbered movement.
==See also== *[[Gym shorts]] *[[Sportswear (activewear)]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = The Burns-Johnson Fight | image = Burns_Johnson.jpg | caption = Poster from film for Hobart screening | director = | producer = [[Charles Cozens Spencer]]{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article109109508 |title=GENERAL NEWS. |newspaper=The Kadina and Wallaroo Times |location=SA |date=2 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}} | writer = | based on = | starring = [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]]
[[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]] | music = | cinematography = [[Ernest Higgins]] | editing = | studio = |distributor = Allan Hamilton{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article95448758 |title=Biograph Pictures. |newspaper=[[Port Pirie Recorder and North Western Mail]] |location=SA |date=30 December 1908 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}} | released = 28 December 1908 (Sydney)[http://www.apex.net.au/~tmj/mp/burns-johnson.htm Tony Martin Jones, "The motion picture of the Burns-Johnson boxing match, 1908" ''Film History''] | runtime = two hours | language = [[Silent film]]
English [[intertitles]] | country = Australia | budget = ₤5,000{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article132258572 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[Illawarra Mercury]] |location=Wollongong, NSW |date=1 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=5 |via=National Library of Australia}} }} '''''The Burns-Johnson Fight''''' (or '''''Burns-Johnson Contest''''') is a 1908 documentary film of the boxing fight between [[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]] and [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] at [[Sydney Stadium]], Rushcutters Bay, on 26 December 1908 for the World Heavyweight Championship title, which Johnson won.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article126738480 |title=THE FIGHT. |newspaper=[[Sunday Times]] |issue=1197 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=27 December 1908 |accessdate=25 April 2016 |page=9 |via=National Library of Australia}} It was produced by [[Charles Cozens Spencer]] at the behest of the fight's promoted [[Hugh D. McIntosh]]. Some footage from the film survives today, chiefly of that showing some of the middle rounds of the 14-round fight. ==Plot== According to newspaper reports the film showed the following: *the champions training, swimming, ball punching, sparring, skipping, motor pacing (Burns at Medlow, Johnson at Botany); *the crowd arriving at the Stadium; *interior preparations; *the ring; *the climax; *view afterwards.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article85917645 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[The Cumberland Argus and Fruitgrowers' Advocate]] |location=Parramatta, NSW |date=10 February 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article57004763 |title=THE BURNS-JOHNSON FIGHT. |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=28 December 1908 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=10 |via=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article158875386 |title=LYRIC THEATRE. |newspaper=Southern Times|location=Bunbury, WA |date=4 March 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=5 |via=National Library of Australia}} According to Hugh MacIntosh:
The show lasts two hours, and not only is the whole fight presented in detail with all the doings between the rounds, but films are shown depicting Johnson and Burns going through their training work, swimming, hall-punching, boxing, massaging, and both. The figures are life-size and there is a wonderful absence of flicker. Then there are films showing the crowds flocking to and from the stadium. What a crowd it was! Nothing has ever been seen like it in Australia.
==Production== [[Hugh D. MacIntosh]] promoted the fight and was also involved in distribution of the film in Queensland in association with [[E. J. Carroll]]. Cameras, films and chemicals worth £2,000 were imported into Australian from England along with two camera experts, who took part in filming with two Australian camera operators. A tower was built 16 feet high to capture vision.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article19554965 |title=BURNSJOHNSON PICTURES. |newspaper=[[The Brisbane Courier]] |date=19 December 1908 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=16 |via=National Library of Australia}} Hugh McIntosh arranged for footage to be taken of Burns and Johnson training and this was shown prior to the fight.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article102793099 |title=THE STRUTTER'S PAGE. |newspaper=[[The Newsletter: an Australian Paper for Australian People]] |location=Sydney |date=12 December 1908 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}} MacIntosh later said:
We went to no end of trouble to secure a good film, and had three machines and operator, at work. One of these latter we imported from a leading French firm to ensure the best talent the world could provide us with, and the importation of this operator and his assistants cost us £500. As events determined, the expense was an unnecessary one; for the best of the three films was the one taken by Mr Spencer, the Australian operator... I am of opinion that the French experts did not fully understand the atmospheric conditions of Australia, and, though we have their films as a standby, it is the one taken by Mr Spencer which we are showing all over the world.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article148615994 |title=THE GREAT FIGHT. |newspaper=Eastern Districts Chronicle (York, WA : 1877–1927) |location=York, WA |date=16 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}
Various newspaper advertisements for the film claim the "general manager" of the movie was [[Alfred Rolfe (director)|Alfred Rolfe]], an actor and stage manager who later made a number of films for Spencer. It is possible this means Rolfe directed, or was involved in the film's New South Wales distribution. [[Raymond Longford]] was also purportedly involved in filming.[http://aso.gov.au/titles/historical/boxing-1908-johnson-vs-burns/notes/ film information] at [[Australian Screen Online]] However this is unlikely as Longford was acting on the stage in Mackay Queensland in December 1908.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article170794152 |title=THE THEATRE. |newspaper=[[Daily Mercury]] |issue=1021 |location=Queensland, Australia |date=28 December 1908 |accessdate=25 April 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}} It was also known as '''''Burns vs Johnson'''''. ==Release== The film was shown almost immediately after the fight, debuting in Sydney at Rushcutter's Bay Stadium on 28 December 1908, to a crowd between 7,000 and 8,000.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113773948 |title=BOXING. |newspaper=[[The Evening News (Sydney)|Evening News]] |issue=12,965 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=29 December 1908 |accessdate=25 April 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}} It was distributed throughout the country. It was also seen overseas. ===Box Office=== The movie was a considerable financial success. According to MacIntosh, the film took £2,114 in one week in Sydney, and £1,738 in Melbourne over four nights. Theatrical manager Allan Hamilton secured rights to distribute the film in Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia for a reported £1,000.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5150286 |title=NEW SOUTH WALES. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=5 December 1908 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=12 |via=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article77111696 |title=BURNS V. JOHNSON. |newspaper=[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]] |location=Perth |date=30 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=13 |via=National Library of Australia}} (Later figures put this at £2,000.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5161133 |title=AMUSEMENTS. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=9 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=9 |via=National Library of Australia}}) It opened in Melbourne on 2 January 1909.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article146723963 |title=BIOGRAPH PICTURES. BURNS-JOHSSON. |newspaper=[[Table Talk (magazine)|Table Talk]] |location=Melbourne |date=31 December 1908 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=22 |via=National Library of Australia}} Melbourne screenings were so successful people were turned away from screenings.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article57555555 |title=FAMOUS FIGHT FILM. |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=6 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}} Spencer was later estimated to have made ₤15,000 from the film.{{Citation | | title=Everyones | publication-date=1920 | publisher=Everyones Ltd | url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.obj-555051303 | accessdate=30 May 2018 }} ===Critical Reception=== According to a contemporary review of a packed out screening:
The various movements in the game were watched with much concern, and the good and bad moves groaned at or cheered according to deserts, while laughter was provoked at frequent intervals by the half-comical episodes that occurred. To make the show realistic, the usual noises, such as the hounding of a gong, and the hooting of tho crowd when the police stopped the light, were provided, and so well was this latter piece co of stage management arranged that the audience on Saturday night, mistaking the bogus hoots for the genuine article, took up the refrain and themselves became hootingly demonstrative.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article120630330 |title=MELBOURNE MEMS. |newspaper=[[The Referee (newspaper)|The Referee]]|location=Sydney |date=6 January 1909 |accessdate=21 February 2015 |page=10 |via=National Library of Australia}}
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://aso.gov.au/titles/historical/boxing-1908-johnson-vs-burns/notes/ film information] at [[Australian Screen Online]] (includes some clips from film) *[https://archive.org/details/JackJohnsonVsTommyBurns Clips from film] at [[Internet Archive]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Burns-Johnson Fight, The}} [[Category:Documentary films about boxing]] [[Category:Australian documentary films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:1908 films]] [[Category:Australian silent feature films]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Jack Johnson]] [[Category:Australian black-and-white films]] [[Category:1900s sports films]] [[Category:1900s documentary films]]

revision.comment: Parentage and grandparentage were previously confused in the text, but correct in the linkage to "Lady Anne FitzRoy," who was to become Anne Lennard, Countess of Sussex.

{{About|the stadium in London|other venues named White City Stadium|White City (disambiguation){{!}}White City}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | name = White City Stadium | image = Le White City Stadium de Londres, pour les JO de 1908.jpg | caption = White City Stadium | location = [[White City, London]], [[England]] | coordinates = {{coord|51.5136|N|0.2274|W|type:landmark_region:GB-HMF_source:enwiki-osgb36(TQ231809)|display=it}} | broke ground = 1907 | opened = 27 April 1908 | closed = 1984 | demolished = 1985 | capacity = 93,000[http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2004/05_may/11/mv_history.pdf History of the White City Site] BBC | surface = Grass | tenants = [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.]] (1931–1933, 1962–1963)
[[Liverpool Stanley#London Highfield .281933.29|London Highfield]] (1933)
[[White City Rebels]] ([[Speedway British League|British League]]) (1976-1978)
[[Greyhound Racing Association]] (1926-1984) }} '''White City Stadium''' in [[White City, London|White City]], [[London]], England, was built for the [[1908 Summer Olympics]], and hosted the finish of the first modern marathon. It also hosted swimming, speedway, boxing, show jumping, athletics, stock car racing, concerts and a match at the [[1966 FIFA World Cup|1966 World Cup]]. From 1927 to 1984, it was a venue for greyhound racing, hosting the [[English Greyhound Derby]]. ==History== Designed by the engineer [[John Webster|J. J. Webster]] and completed in 10 months by [[George Wimpey]],White, p. 5 on part of the site of the [[Franco-British Exhibition (1908)|Franco-British Exhibition]], this stadium with a seating capacity of 68,000 was opened by [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VII]] on 27 April 1908 after the first stanchion had been placed in position by Lady Desborough on 2 August 1907. The cost of construction was [[Pound sterling|£]]60,000.{{cite journal | last = Zarnowski | first = C. Frank |date=Summer 1992 | title = A Look at Olympic Costs | journal = Citius, Altius, Fortius | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 16–32 | url = http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JOH/JOHv1n1/JOHv1n1f.pdf | accessdate =24 March 2007}} Upon completion, the stadium had a running track {{convert|24|ft|m|abbr=on|adj=mid|wide}} and three laps to the mile (536 m); outside there was a {{convert|35|ft|m|adj=mid|-wide}}, {{convert|660|yd|m|adj=on}} cycle track. The infield included a swimming and diving pool. [[File:Franco-British Exhibition, 1908 (3057429205).jpg|thumb|The 1908 Franco-British Exhibition site seen from the air. The White City Stadium is to the right of the view]] [[File:White City Stadium 1908.jpg|thumb|350px|The White City Stadium during the 1908 Summer Olympics]] Many events of the [[1908 Olympics]] were at the stadium itself whereas nowadays there are many arenas. [[Rugby union at the 1908 Summer Olympics|The Olympic rugby union final]] between [[Australia]] and [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain]] was held in the stadium on 26 October 1908The First Hundred Years - The story of rugby in Cornwall by Tom Salmon 1983 (published by the Cornwall RFU)[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1908/1908.pdf 1908 Summer Olympics official report. pp. 32-5, 40.] and events such as archery and gymnastics took place at White City, while some others took place at [[Queens Club]]. Swimming was held at White City, in a 100-yard pool dug in the infield. The position of the finish line for the [[marathon]] in the 1908 Summer Olympics is commemorated by a marker in the plaza that now stands there. The distance of the modern marathon was fixed at these Games and calculated from the start of the race at [[Windsor Castle]] to a point in front of the royal box. The medal table for the [[1908 Summer Olympics]] is also listed on a nearby wall.The photographing of the plaques is not allowed without prior permission. The original running track continued in use until 1914. There were attempts to sell the stadium in 1922, but several athletes in the team for the [[1924 Summer Olympics]] used it for training. In 1926 the GRA ([[Greyhound Racing Association]]) took over the stadium and in 1927, the track was grassed over for [[greyhound racing]] and [[motorcycle speedway|speedway]]. They built new covered terracing and a restaurant. From 1927 until its closure it hosted weekly greyhound meetings and was considered the top greyhound track in Britain. It hosted the sport's premier event, the [[English Greyhound Derby]], until 1984. Just before and after the Second World War attendances were huge, a record 92,000 spectators attended the 1939 Derby final. In 1931, a 440yd running track was installed for the [[Amateur Athletic Association]] Championships, held there from 1932 to 1970. Besides the AAA championships, major athletics events, including international matches, were held at the stadium. In 1954 in a match against Russia [[Christopher Chataway]] broke the world 5000m record running against [[Vladimir Kuts]]. The one mile world record was broken there by [[Derek Ibbotson]] in 1957. In 1934 the [[1934 British Empire Games|second British Empire Games]] and the [[1934 Women's World Games|fourth Women's World Games]] were held at the venue. Also in 1931, [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.]] began the first of two spells playing at the stadium, until 1933 (the second spell was from 1962–63). QPR eventually decided against a permanent move to White City and stayed at [[Loftus Road]]. [[File:Canada-United States football game at White City Stadium, London, 1944.jpg|thumb|Team captains shake hands after a Canada-United States American football game at White City Stadium, 14 February 1944]] Between 1932 and 1958 the stadium hosted major British boxing events, with attendances peaking as high as 90,000 for the second meeting between [[Len Harvey]] and [[Jack Petersen]] in 1934. The first major fight at the stadium was Len Harvey’s unsuccessful challenge for the NBA Middleweight Championship versus [[Marcel Thil]] of France. Future heavyweight champion [[Primo Carnera]] suffered his only defeat on British soil here when he lost to Canadian [[Larry Gains]] in May 1932. Other important fighters to appear at White City include [[Jock McAvoy]], [[Don Cockell]], [[Nino Valdez]], [[Henry Cooper]] and [[Terry Downes]]. In 1933, Wigan Highfield, a [[rugby league]] side, nearly became bankrupt. White City Company, owners of the stadium, decided to move the club to [[White City, London|White City]]. Previously, only [[rugby union]] had been popular in southern England, professional [[rugby league]] being the preserve of northern towns and cities. [[Liverpool Stanley#Wigan Highfield - 1880-1895 and 1902-1933|Wigan Highfield]] became [[Liverpool Stanley#London Highfield - 1933|London Highfield]] with their debts paid. Their first try was scored by George "Porky" Davies, who went on to play for [[Liverpool Stanley#Liverpool Stanley - 1934-1951 and the second Liverpool City - 1951-1968|Liverpool Stanley]] and then [[St Helens R.F.C.|St. Helens]] from 1938 to 1947. The White City Company lost money on the venture and decided not to continue with rugby league. London Highfield was the precursor to [[London Broncos]], the current leading rugby league club in London. In 1966, [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Wembley's]] owner's refusal to cancel regular greyhound racing meant the match between [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] and [[France national football team|France]] in the [[1966 FIFA World Cup]] was played at White City. The game attracted 45,662 fans. The stadium was demolished in 1985 and the site is now occupied by [[BBC White City]]. ==Greyhound Racing== {{main article|White City Greyhounds}} White City Stadium was principally used for [[greyhound racing]] for the majority of its existence. The first greyhound meeting took place on 20 June 1927.{{cite web | url = http://www.stainforthonline.co.uk/2001/meadow_court_racing_history.htm | title = A Concise History Greyhound Racing | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | publisher = Stainforth OnLine}} The stadium became the Mecca of greyhound racing with tens of thousands of spectators attending meetings on a regular basis, particularly in the 1940s, and 1950s. A crowd of 92,000 attended the [[1939 English Greyhound Derby]] final.{{cite book|last=Dack|first=Barrie|title=Greyhound Derby, the first 60 years|year=1990|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-36-8}} ===Competitions=== The track was renowned for holding some of the sports top events in addition to the [[English Greyhound Derby]]. They included the [[The Grand National - Greyhounds|Grand National]], the [[The Oaks - Greyhounds|Oaks]], the Wood Lane Stakes, the Longcross Cup and the Cambridgeshire.{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The National Greyhound Racing Club Book of Greyhound Racing|year=1990|publisher=pelhambooks|isbn=0-7207-1804-X}} The final Greyhound Derby was held on 23 June 1984. ==Speedway== The [[motorcycle speedway|speedway track]] at White City was {{convert|380|m|yd|abbr=off}} in length. The White City stadium first held open speedway meetings in 1928 before the start of the Southern League, in 1929. A team from the stadium known as White City (London) entered the 1929 Southern League where they finished in 7th place out of 11 teams (after Birmingham (Hall Green) resigned for the league after racing 7 league matches). The White City team were due to race in the 1930 Southern League, but they withdrew from the league before it started. The stadium then ran once again using an Open Licence and held occasional one-off meetings between (1953–58, 1961) until a new league team was formed, from the Oxford 'Rebels' in 1976. From 1976 until 1978, the stadium was home to [[White City Rebels]] speedway team.Bamford, R & Jarvis J.(2001). ''Homes of British Speedway''. {{ISBN|0-7524-2210-3}} The team closed after only three seasons due to poor crowds levels, despite finishing the 1977 season as champions of the [[Speedway British League|British League]]. The Rebels' most notable rider was [[England national speedway team|England]] International [[Gordon Kennett]]. Other notable riders were [[Steve Weatherley]], [[Trevor Geer]], [[Poland]]'s [[Marek Cieślak]] and multiple [[Finland|Finnish]] champion [[Kai Niemi]] and [[Colin Watson (speedway rider)|Colin Watson]] (pre war).Jacobs, N. ''Speedway in London'', {{ISBN|0-7524-2221-9}} From 1979-83 the stadium once again raced using an Open Licence hosting a number of high-profile [[Speedway World Championship]] qualifying rounds, including the Overseas and [[Intercontinental Final|Intercontinental]] Finals during the 1970s, and 1980s. It also hosted the Final of the [[Speedway World Team Cup]] in [[1976 Speedway World Team Cup|1976]], [[1979 Speedway World Team Cup|1979]] and [[1982 Speedway World Team Cup|1982]]. Following the end of speedway at the [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] after the [[1981 Individual Speedway World Championship|1981 World Final]], White City became the home of international speedway in Great Britain until it was closed in 1984. Following this international speedway moved out of London and north to the [[Odsal Stadium]] in [[Bradford]]. ===Speedway World Finals=== ====World Team Cup==== * [[1976 Speedway World Team Cup|1976]] - {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Australia national speedway team|Australia]] ([[John Boulger]] / [[Phil Crump]] / [[Billy Sanders]] / [[Phil Herne]] / [[Garry Middleton]]) - 42pts * [[1979 Speedway World Team Cup|1979]] - {{flagicon|NZL}} [[New Zealand national speedway team|New Zealand]] ([[Ivan Mauger]] / [[Larry Ross]] / [[Mitch Shirra]] / [[Bruce Cribb]] / [[Roger Abel (speedway rider)|Roger Abel]]) - 35pts * [[1982 Speedway World Team Cup|1982]] - {{flagicon|USA}} [[United States national speedway team|United States]] ([[Bruce Penhall]] / [[Bobby Schwartz]] / [[Kelly Moran (speedway rider)|Kelly Moran]] / [[Shawn Moran]] / [[Scott Autrey]]) - 34pts ==Appearances in the media== The White City Stadium features in the climax to the 1950 film ''[[The Blue Lamp]]''. It also appears in an episode, named "Man From the Dead", of 1960s television spy series ''[[Man in a Suitcase]]'' and was used in the 1973 film ''[[Steptoe and Son Ride Again]]''. Some sections of the video for [[The Human League]] single "[[Life On Your Own]]" were shot in the stadium in 1984, just a few months before its demolition. The stadium was the location of a famous public outburst by [[Ray Davies]] of [[The Kinks]] during a July 1973 performance.Hinman, Doug (2004). p. 174 Davies swore onstage,Hollingsworth, Roy (21 July 1973). "Thank you for the days, Ray". ''[[Melody Maker]]''. and at the show's conclusion, as pretaped music played on the sound system, declared his retirement from the group. He subsequently collapsed after a drug overdose and was rushed to hospital.George, Chris (27 August 1994). "The Kitchen Sink Kink". ''[[The Independent]]''. He would eventually recover and return to recording with The Kinks.Portions of the preceding paragraph copied from the Wikipedia article [[The Kinks]], section "Theatrical Incarnation: 1973–1976" At a [[David Cassidy]] show on 26 May 1974, 800 people were injured in a crush at the front of the stage.{{cite news | title = 14 girls hurt in crush at Cassidy concert | date = 27 May 1974 | work = The Times }} Thirty were taken to hospital, and one, 14-year-old Bernadette Whelan, died on 30 May from injuries. [[The Pogues]] made a song about the stadium and its demolition, called "White City". It can be found on their 1989 album ''[[Peace and Love (The Pogues album)|Peace and Love]]''. ==See also== *[[Rugby union at the 1908 Summer Olympics]] *[[List of Commonwealth Games venues]]
